question: Question_09_(d)
statement:
\emph{Each of the short-answer questions below is worth 5 points. Put
your answer in the box provided and show your work. No credit will be
given for the answer without the correct accompanying work.}

Determine whether the improper integral

\begin{align*}\int_0^2 \frac{2x}{1-x^2} dx\end{align*}

is convergent or divergent. If convergent, write the value of the
integral in the box. If not, write ``divergent'' and explain why in the
space provided below.
sols:
We want to determine whether the integral

\begin{align*}\int_0^2 \frac{2x}{1-x^2}\, dx\end{align*}

converges. We notice that the integrand is not defined at the point
$x=1$ so the integral is improper. Hence, we break up the integral at
this discontinuity to get that

$\int_0^2 \frac{2x}{1-x^2}\, dx = \lim_{b \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{b}\frac{2x}{1-x^2}\, dx + \lim_{a \to 1^{+}}\int_{a}^{2}\frac{2x}{1-x^2}\, dx$

To evaluate the first integral, we use a substitution namely
$u = 1 - x^{2}$ and get that $du = -2xdx$. The endpoints change to
$u(0) = 1-(0)^{2} = 1$ and $u(b) = 1 - b^{2}$

\begin{align*}
 \lim_{b \to 1^{-}}\int_{0}^{b}\frac{2x}{1-x^2}\, dx &= \lim_{b \to 1^{-}}\int_{1}^{1 - b^{2}}\frac{-du}{u}\\
&= \lim_{b \to 1^{-}} \big(-\ln|u|\big) \big|_{1}^{1-b^{2}} \\
&= \lim_{b \to 1^{-}}-\ln(1-b^{2}) + \ln(1) \end{align*}

and this last limit evaluates to negative infinity. Hence, the integral
diverges.
hints:
Check to make sure that the integral makes sense. Where is the integral
not defined?

An improper integral

$\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\, dx$

with the discontinuity at the point $c$ in the interval from $a$ to $b$
converges if and only if

$\lim_{t \to c^{-}} \int_{a}^{t}f(x)\, dx$

and

$\lim_{s \to c^{+}} \int_{s}^{b}f(x)\, dx$

both converge.
